Award.AwardTitle: Cladding-Pumped Silicon Raman Amplifiers Integrated with In(Ga)As Quantum Dot Laser Pumps

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Objective: The objective of this program is to demonstrate InGaAs/GaAs quantum dot laser grown on dislocation filters on silicon substrates that will be used as a pump source for cladding-pumped Si Raman amplifiers integrated on the same chip. Planarization via etching the substrates and regrowth inside the formed trenches will make it possible to couple the laser pump directly into Si waveguides. The upper cladding of Si waveguides will be formed using silicon-oxynitride. The core Si waveguide will be fabricated by shrinking the cross-section dimensions of patterned waveguides via thermal oxidation.
Intellectual merit: The intellectual merit is the first demonstration of high-performance hybrid III-V on Si lasers and their integration with Si Raman amplifiers. High-performance hybrid Si lasers have been elusive and their demonstration is transformative. Demonstration of a high-gain silicon optical amplifier integrated with a pump source is also transformative and is considered a milestone in integrated photonics. The proposed waveguide fabrication technique avoids the difficulties of electron-beam lithography for submicron waveguide fabrication.
Broader impacts: The broader impacts are the interdisciplinary nature of the program, its undergraduate and underrepresented minorities and K-12 outreach. The proposed program provides a broader impact to science and society beyond technical merits. It combines optoelectronics with microelectronics, physics, and materials science and engineering, thereby extends optoelectronics to real applications. The proposed program outlines interdisciplinary research for graduate and undergraduate students. Outreach projects for women and underrepresented minorities are highlighted. The program proposes to expose middle- and high-school students to scientific and engineering disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Imagine when you talk on your smart phone, Google something with it, or even when you set it on ‘airplane mode’ and just listen to your favorite songs offline. In all these ‘applications’, electrons or ‘photons’ (light particles) ought to move around to transfer data within your phone’s brain or ‘microprocessor’ or memory racks of a Google data center facility and else. With many challenges facing metallic (copper or aluminum) wires, ‘optical wires’ have been replacing metals for shorter and shorter distances. To see where the technology is heading, imagine a laser in your future game console motherboard providing light for ultra-fast transfer of huge amount of data between various microprocessors, memories and your high-definition three-dimensional monitor.

To implement the above, optics and electronics must marry and live on the same microchip. Active optical devices (mainly lasers) have been traditionally on materials like Gallium Arsenide, while electronics has been on silicon. Recently, passive optics on silicon has been realized too. So, if a technology exists that can integrate Gallium-Arsenide lasers on silicon, optics and photonics can live together. This program aimed at this goal and particularly develops technologies to integrate lasers with waveguides, particularly for silicon optical amplifiers.

To this end, submicron double-cladding silicon waveguides were achieved for the first time and the properties of subwavelength nanopartures were studied for waveguide coupling applications. Gold-to-gold cold-weld was used for bonding Gallium-Arsenide laser chips to etched silicon substrates and quantum dot lasers were integrated with silicon-nitride waveguides on the same silicon chip.
